item.title: Conclusion
item.description: This has been a short guide of all the advanced rockbox theming things I know. Hopefully this helps people new to rockbox, and myself in the future when I return to making themes and inevitably forget everything. Thanks for reading!

item.title: 4. Unused Functions
item.description: ∘ The xd tag - This might seem like an odd choice, the most used tag of all? But it actually has a different way using it that’s almost never used! The usual way is labelling images by a single letter, this is incredibly handy for writing stuff like battery indicators manually. However, the label can actual be anything you want! As written here on the Wiki: %xd(label, <subimage number> [, offset]) Using the tag like this opens a huge amount of functionality, as well as making your code more readable.

item.title: 3. Overlay Images
item.description: Drawing overlays in Rockbox is a neat trick to mask sections of the screen to create unique interface designs. While mostly used to create rounded corners on album art, the technique can actually be applied to any part of the screen. How it works Rockbox sees a specific RGB Value as transparent (another value it sees as the foreground colour) you can read more about it in the Notes of this section of the Wiki.

item.title: 2. Lockscreen
item.description: The FreshOS Lockscreen by Yuuiko There’s a rich history of Rockbox themes using the hold switch for additional functionality, however they followed the idea of showing extra info, or displaying album art. In comparison, Yuuiko uses the hold switch to unlock entirely unique screens in a way that enhances the capabilities of Rockbox. How it works The setup for lockscreens is surprisingly simple. It takes the same concept of background switching we’ve seen, but combines it with the function for the hold switch, allowing us to define what should be displayed when the switch is on and off!

item.title: 1. Backdrop Switching
item.description: When it comes to making more advanced themes, switching backdrops is the door to most things. item.title: Rockbox Theming
item.description: In recent years, there have been many developments in the rockbox theming space. New ways of abstracting the theme tags rockbox uses to customise it’s UI have been created to give users even more functionality and better themes than ever before. However, a lot of these tricks are not well documented and involve being quite familiar with how rockbox theming works in order to extrapolate their construction. This guide intends to be a collection of these tricks, how to make them, as well as discussing some newer or rarely-used tags in rockbox.
